column1: File:Abe Papakhian - Elendil and Sons.jpgHigh King was a title used by the Dúnedain for their ultimate ruler. Normally
column2: "High King" would refer to a king who ruled over other lesser kings and lords
column3: but this is not necessarily the case with the High King of the Dúnedain. The term seems to date back to the early days of Númenor
column4: where Tar-Meneldur the fifth King was addressed as "High King"
column5: though he had no other rulers in his service.

column1: The more common use of the title
column3: came at the end of the Second Age
column4: with the establishment of the Realms in Exile in Middle-earth. In their earliest years
column5: the Reunited Kingdom of Arnor and Gondor fell under the ultimate rule of one man
column7: who dwelt in Arnor as the High King. The South-kingdom of Gondor was ruled jointly by his sons

column1: With Elendils loss in the Siege of Barad-dûr
column2: his elder son Isildur inherited the High Kingship. Isildur ruled for only two years
column4: before he too was lost in the Disaster of the Gladden Fields. After his death
column5: historical events conspired to separate the Two Kingdoms
column6: each of which took Kings of their own. The High Kingship should in principle have fallen on Isildurs heir Valandil (King of Arnor)
column7: but in practice Valandil became King of Arnor only
column8: and had no power over the South-kingdom.

column1: More than three thousand years were to pass before Aragorn Reunited Kingdom Elendils realms. In doing so
column2: as the direct descendant of Isildur
column5: he also resurrected the High Kingship.
